request_pathways.name: Patient Authorization for Disclosure of PHI
Mail completed form to Medical Records Department
Drop off completed form at hospital main lobby

forms.document_type: Combined instructions + ROI authorization form (COVID-era cover page with older form)

access_pathway.primary_pathway_description: Patient downloads a generic HIPAA authorization form, prints and handwrites all fields, then mails or drops off the completed form at the hospital.

barriers.response_time_value: 3-5 business days processing; 2 business days for electronic delivery, 7-10 for mail
red_flags: Broad liability waiver: patient must agree not to hold Grady responsible for anything that may happen from use or release of PHI
Completeness threat: form states it may be considered invalid if any selection is incomplete
Collects last four digits of SSN in addition to requiring government-issued photo ID
bright_spots: Encrypted email delivery option available on current form
Fee disclosure on form-3 cover page: charges generally do not exceed $6.50; continuing care requests are free
Processing time estimates provided (3-5 business days, 2 days electronic, 7-10 days mail)
Multiple record delivery formats: paper, CD, encrypted email

findability.rationale: Level 4: Forms directly linked from gradyhealth.org/medical-records/ and found on first web search with no login, bot blocking, or broken links.

technical_accessibility.rationale: Level 2: Primarily a paper workflow — the PDF has zero fillable fields (print and handwrite required), and submission is limited to mail or in-person drop-off with no fax, email, or portal submission available.

content_design.rationale: Level 3: Adequate organization with clear section flow and granular record type options, but notable problems including dense legal language, a broad liability waiver, ambiguous sensitive information handling, and a threatening completeness warning.

patient_centeredness.rationale: Level 3: A patient can use the generic authorization form for self-access (it includes 'Personal' as a purpose and addresses patient requests in documentation requirements), but the form was designed for third-party release and the patient must navigate the from/to disclosure structure.

compliance.rationale: Level 3: Some requirements that may go beyond what the law requires — broad liability waiver bundled with authorization, SSN collection alongside photo ID, and threatening completeness language — offset by proper revocation rights, no-conditioning statement, and reasonable expiration.

overall.summary: Grady Memorial Hospital makes forms easy to find and offers some progressive delivery options like encrypted email, but the entirely paper-based submission workflow, non-fillable forms, generic third-party authorization design, and broad liability waiver significantly limit patient-centeredness and accessibility.
